bibl.title: Memorandum from Juan Guiteras and Aristides Agramonte to Charles E. Magoon, November 24, 1908

div1.p: Guiteras and Agramonte describe a case of yellow fever.

div1.head: Memorandum from Juan Guiteras and Aristides Agramonte to Charles E. Magoon, November 24, 1908
div1.p:
Ramiro Sueiro, a Spaniard, without occupation or home, and
believed to be a pickpocket, was taken sick with yellow fever on
the 7th of September and died on September 18th, having been
transferred from Mercedes Hospital on September 11th as a sus-
picious case, to the Hospital Las Animas. He slept at a posada
in San Pedro No. 3 from August 26th to September 4th, from which
time until the 7th he was said to have slept in an abandoned
block house at Triscornia. From the 7th until the 11th he
spent on the streets, being admitted to Mercedes Hospital on
the latter date and transferred at once to Las Animas, as above
stated. The following is the report of the autopsy made by the
Commission of Diagnosis of Infectious Diseases:

Sir:- This morning in the Hospital Las Animas the Commission on
Infectious Diseases met, there being present, Drs. Finlay, Gui-
teras, Albertini, Lainé and Agramonte, members, and also Drs.
Amesse and Ponce de Leon, visitors. The Commission proceeded to
make the autopsy of the body of Ramiro Sueiro, diagnosed yellow
fever on the 14th instant. They found a perfect classical pict-
ure, both anatomically and pathologically of yellow fever. The
liver was the color of chamois and in a condition of fatty de-
generation. The kidneys showed parenchymatous naphritis. The
stomach contained 125 c.c. of black vomit, and there was exten-
sive hemorrhage in the inferior lobes of both lungs. Jaundice
was well marked, but not intense. All of which we have the honor
to communicate to you.
